prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain the first sample of photometry in Band 7, the reference band, of 252P's point-source nucleus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: We request observations during the two-week period when the comet is brightest. Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard correlator setup for continuum-only observations. We want to maximize the probability of detecting the comet in all bands, given that the nucleus size is still quite unknown, so we would use all 7.5 GHz. We have used the central frequencies that are suggested in Table 6.1 of the Technical Handbook.
The nucleus will be a point-source, and we do not expect emission from dust. We can accept any configuration the array is in during late March.

The standard way to predict nucleus fluxes is to use 'NEATM', the Near-Earth Asteroid Thermal Model (Harris 1998). It is applicable to cometary nuclei that are weakly active. The model divides up the nucleus into facets and calculates a temperature for each facet based on the Sun's position and an assumed thermal conductivity. Then it uses the Planck function to calculate the emission from each facet, and does the integral to derive the total flux density emitted.
Figure 1 shows the predicted flux density over time in the seven ALMA bands. We assumed the surface thermal conductivity was negligible, which is consistent with results for other comets. The figure shows curves for two assumed values of emissivity, 0.95 and 0.6. The radius is unknown but we assumed 0.5 km, which is a conservative estimate for an intrinsically-faint comet (e.g. Fernandez et al. 2013). The radius will be constrained by visible, IR, and radar observations during the apparition, so we expect to have this parameter for our analysis. Note that the NEATM does not account for temperature at depths; it assumes the temperature of the surface is valid, but we can mimic the effect by simply lowering the emissivity. The lower plot in Figure 1 does this, but it's the same effect as if the temperature were lower by 10%. We request that observations happen during the last two weeks of March, around the time the comet is brightest (March 21). The March 16 to 30 period represents the time when the nucleus's flux is >50% of the maximum. We emphasize that since the nucleus's radius is unknown, it might be smaller, so we really need to observe when the comet is brightest.
Our requested sensitivities are: 0.023 mJy in Band 3, 0.052 mJy in Band 4, 0.13 mJy in Band 6, 0.29 mJy in Band 7, 0.40 mJy in Band 8, 1.1 mJy in Band 9, and 2.1 mJy in Band 10. The frequencies are those given in Table 6.1 of the Technical Handbook. We justify the sensitivities themselves below.
Since we want absolute photometry, we are constrained by the absolute calibration. The Technical Handbook (section 10.5) says that such calibration will only be good to 15% in Band 9 and 5% in Band 3. We interpolate and assume that the absolute calibration will be good to 20% in Band 10, 15% in Band 8, 10% in Bands 7 and 6, and 5% in Band 4. Therefore we only need enough time to achieve enough S/N in the raw photometry such that the absolute calibration is the dominant contributor to the error budget. Thus our observational goal is to achieve S/N=25 in Band 10, and S/N=30 in the other six bands.
To derive a sensitivity for each band, we used Figure 1, using a pessimistic scenario where the observations occur on March 16. To find the sensitivity, we simply divided the flux by the required S/N.
Including the calibration error, we expect to get S/N~4.9 in Band 10, S/N~6.5 in Bands 9 and 8, S/N~9.5 in Bands 7 and 6, and S/N~16 in Bands 4 and 3. This is adequate, as shown in Figure 2. First, diamonds show fluxes from March 16 in Figure 1 (top); with this photometry, and the known nucleus radius, we can extract the temperature from the overall scale of the flux (of course obviously not from the spectral slope for an R-J law).
Next, note the circles in Figure 2. The error bars are the same as for the diamonds, but here we have suppressed the fluxes by ~40%, as if the brightness temperature had dropped by about 10%. If these were our measured photometry, we would be able to tell that the temperature at mm-depth is lower than the surface temperature, i.e. that we have sampled a cooler layer.
Lastly, note the squares in Figure 2. Here we have assumed that emissivity or temperature has an empirical trend with inverse wavelength. If these were our measured photometry, we would be able to tell that there was a temperature or emissivity trend with depth. Depending on the actual slope of the line, we would be able to constrain the actual temperature gradient, probably the most exciting result possible.

As Figure 1 shows, we must observe in the second-half of March. Outside of the time, the comet is much fainter than it is at its peak brightness. Since we do not know for sure the nucleus's size, it is best to be conservative and only try to observe the comet during the two-week period when it will be brightest.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain the photometry in Band 10 of 252P's point-source nucleus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: We request observations during the two-week period when the comet is brightest. Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

******************************************************************************* Column meaning:
TIME
Prior to 1962, times are UT1. Dates thereafter are UTC. Any 'b' symbol in the 1st-column denotes a B.C. date. First-column blank (" ") denotes an A.D. date. Calendar dates prior to 1582-Oct-15 are in the Julian calendar system. Later calendar dates are in the Gregorian system.
Time tags refer to the same instant throughout the universe, regardless of where the observer is located.
The dynamical Coordinate Time scale is used internally. It is equivalent to the current IAU definition of "TDB". Conversion between CT and the selected non-uniform UT output scale has not been determined for UTC times after the next July or January 1st. The last known leap-second is used over any future interval.
NOTE: "n.a." in output means quantity "not available" at the print-time.
SOLAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) Time tag is followed by a blank, then a solar-presence symbol:
'*' Daylight (refracted solar upper-limb on or above apparent horizon) 'C' Civil twilight/dawn 'N' Nautical twilight/dawn 'A' Astronomical twilight/dawn ' ' Night OR geocentric ephemeris
LUNAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) The solar-presence symbol is immediately followed by a lunar-presence symbol:
'm' Refracted upper-limb of Moon on or above apparent horizon ' ' Refracted upper-limb of Moon below apparent horizon OR geocentric ephemeris
R.A._(ICRF/J2000.0)_DEC = J2000.0 astrometric right ascension and declination of target center. Adjusted for light-time. Units: HMS (HH MM SS.ff) and DMS (DD MM SS.f)
delta deldot = Range ("delta") and range-rate ("delta-dot") of target center with respect to the observer at the instant light seen by the observer at print-time would have left the target center (print-time minus down-leg light-time); the distance traveled by a light ray emanating from the center of the target and recorded by the observer at print-time. "deldot" is a projection of the velocity vector along this ray, the light-time-corrected line-of-sight from the coordinate center, and indicates relative motion. A positive "deldot" means the target center is moving away from the observer (coordinate center). A negative "deldot" means the target center is moving toward the observer. Units: AU and KM/S
Computations by ... Solar System Dynamics Group, Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System 4800 Oak Grove Drive, Jet Propulsion Laboratory Pasadena, CA 91109 USA Information: http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/ Connect : telnet://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov:6775 (via browser) telnet ssd.jpl.nasa.gov 6775 (via command-line) Author : Jon.Giorgini@jpl.nasa.gov

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard correlator setup for continuum-only observations.
The nucleus will be a point-source, and we do not expect emission from dust. We can accept any configuration the array is in during late March.

See text for SG1. Here is the justification for why we must observe in Band 7 multiple times:
Cometary nuclei are elongated objects that spin; hence they show a variable cross section to an observer over time. Comet 252P's spin state is not known; for this reason, observations where each wavelength is separated widely in time (hours or longer) would be uninterpretable.
Furthermore, since the comet would likely rotate significantly as we observed from band to band, we need rotational context. Therefore we must observe the comet in one of the bands multiple times so we know how to interpret the results in the other bands. We have chosen Band 7 to be this band since it gets us the best S/N in the shortest time. We bracket the Band 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, and 10 observations with Band 7 snapshots.
For these reasons our proposed observations must occur all consecutively as one scheduled block, with the SGs executed in the numerical order indicated by their names.

As Figure 1 shows, we must observe in the second-half of March. Outside of the time, the comet is much fainter than it is at its peak brightness. Since we do not know for sure the nucleus's size, it is best to be conservative and only try to observe the comet during the two-week period when it will be brightest.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain the third sample of photometry in Band 7, the reference band, of 252P's point-source nucleus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: We request observations during the two-week period when the comet is brightest. Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard correlator setup for continuum-only observations.
The nucleus will be a point-source, and we do not expect emission from dust. We can accept any configuration the array is in during late March.
Please see text in SG1 and SG3 for information about the sensitivity and bandwidth.

As Figure 1 shows, we must observe in the second-half of March. Outside of the time, the comet is much fainter than it is at its peak brightness. Since we do not know for sure the nucleus's size, it is best to be conservative and only try to observe the comet during the two-week period when it will be brightest.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain the fifth sample of photometry in Band 7, the reference band, of 252P's point-source nucleus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: We request observations during the two-week period when the comet is brightest. Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

******************************************************************************* Column meaning:
TIME
Prior to 1962, times are UT1. Dates thereafter are UTC. Any 'b' symbol in the 1st-column denotes a B.C. date. First-column blank (" ") denotes an A.D. date. Calendar dates prior to 1582-Oct-15 are in the Julian calendar system. Later calendar dates are in the Gregorian system.
Time tags refer to the same instant throughout the universe, regardless of where the observer is located.
The dynamical Coordinate Time scale is used internally. It is equivalent to the current IAU definition of "TDB". Conversion between CT and the selected non-uniform UT output scale has not been determined for UTC times after the next July or January 1st. The last known leap-second is used over any future interval.
NOTE: "n.a." in output means quantity "not available" at the print-time.
SOLAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) Time tag is followed by a blank, then a solar-presence symbol:
'*' Daylight (refracted solar upper-limb on or above apparent horizon) 'C' Civil twilight/dawn 'N' Nautical twilight/dawn 'A' Astronomical twilight/dawn ' ' Night OR geocentric ephemeris
LUNAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) The solar-presence symbol is immediately followed by a lunar-presence symbol:
'm' Refracted upper-limb of Moon on or above apparent horizon ' ' Refracted upper-limb of Moon below apparent horizon OR geocentric ephemeris
R.A._(ICRF/J2000.0)_DEC = J2000.0 astrometric right ascension and declination of target center. Adjusted for light-time. Units: HMS (HH MM SS.ff) and DMS (DD MM SS.f)
delta deldot = Range ("delta") and range-rate ("delta-dot") of target center with respect to the observer at the instant light seen by the observer at print-time would have left the target center (print-time minus down-leg light-time); the distance traveled by a light ray emanating from the center of the target and recorded by the observer at print-time. "deldot" is a projection of the velocity vector along this ray, the light-time-corrected line-of-sight from the coordinate center, and indicates relative motion. A positive "deldot" means the target center is moving away from the observer (coordinate center). A negative "deldot" means the target center is moving toward the observer. Units: AU and KM/S

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard correlator setup for continuum-only observations.
The nucleus will be a point-source, and we do not expect emission from dust. We can accept any configuration the array is in during late March.
Please see text in SG1 and SG3 for information about the sensitivity and bandwidth.

As Figure 1 shows, we must observe in the second-half of March. Outside of the time, the comet is much fainter than it is at its peak brightness. Since we do not know for sure the nucleus's size, it is best to be conservative and only try to observe the comet during the two-week period when it will be brightest.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain the photometry in Band 9 of 252P's point-source nucleus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: We request observations during the two-week period when the comet is brightest. Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard correlator setup for continuum-only observations.
The nucleus will be a point-source, and we do not expect emission from dust. We can accept any configuration the array is in during late March.
Please see text in SG1 for information about the sensitivity and bandwidth.

As Figure 1 shows, we must observe in the second-half of March. Outside of the time, the comet is much fainter than it is at its peak brightness. Since we do not know for sure the nucleus's size, it is best to be conservative and only try to observe the comet during the two-week period when it will be brightest.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain the photometry in Band 6 of 252P's point-source nucleus.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: We request observations during the two-week period when the comet is brightest. Furthermore, we request that the SGs be executed in their numbered order and with no gaps, since it is crucial that we interleave Band 7 observations within the other band observations so as to account for the rotational context.

******************************************************************************* Column meaning:
TIME
Prior to 1962, times are UT1. Dates thereafter are UTC. Any 'b' symbol in the 1st-column denotes a B.C. date. First-column blank (" ") denotes an A.D. date. Calendar dates prior to 1582-Oct-15 are in the Julian calendar system. Later calendar dates are in the Gregorian system.
Time tags refer to the same instant throughout the universe, regardless of where the observer is located.
The dynamical Coordinate Time scale is used internally. It is equivalent to the current IAU definition of "TDB". Conversion between CT and the selected non-uniform UT output scale has not been determined for UTC times after the next July or January 1st. The last known leap-second is used over any future interval.
NOTE: "n.a." in output means quantity "not available" at the print-time.
SOLAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) Time tag is followed by a blank, then a solar-presence symbol:
'*' Daylight (refracted solar upper-limb on or above apparent horizon) 'C' Civil twilight/dawn 'N' Nautical twilight/dawn 'A' Astronomical twilight/dawn ' ' Night OR geocentric ephemeris
LUNAR PRESENCE (OBSERVING SITE) The solar-presence symbol is immediately followed by a lunar-presence symbol:
'm' Refracted upper-limb of Moon on or above apparent horizon ' ' Refracted upper-limb of Moon below apparent horizon OR geocentric ephemeris
R.A._(ICRF/J2000.0)_DEC = J2000.0 astrometric right ascension and declination of target center. Adjusted for light-time. Units: HMS (HH MM SS.ff) and DMS (DD MM SS.f)
delta deldot = Range ("delta") and range-rate ("delta-dot") of target center with respect to the observer at the instant light seen by the observer at print-time would have left the target center (print-time minus down-leg light-time); the distance traveled by a light ray emanating from the center of the target and recorded by the observer at print-time. "deldot" is a projection of the velocity vector along this ray, the light-time-corrected line-of-sight from the coordinate center, and indicates relative motion. A positive "deldot" means the target center is moving away from the observer (coordinate center). A negative "deldot" means the target center is moving toward the observer. Units: AU and KM/S

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request standard correlator setup for continuum-only observations.
The nucleus will be a point-source, and we do not expect emission from dust. We can accept any configuration the array is in during late March.
Please see text in SG1 for information about the sensitivity and bandwidth.

As Figure 1 shows, we must observe in the second-half of March. Outside of the time, the comet is much fainter than it is at its peak brightness. Since we do not know for sure the nucleus's size, it is best to be conservative and only try to observe the comet during the two-week period when it will be brightest.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the submm- and mm-wave continuum thermal emission from the nucleus of comet 252P/LINEAR as it passes only 0.036 AU from Earth in March 2016. The proposed observations would be part of a broader campaign to also obtain continuum detections at cm-wavelengths with the VLA, and thereby make the rare achievement of measuring a comet nucleus's SED at excellent S/N over almost two decades of radio wavelengths. We emphasize however that our science goals can be achieved just with ALMA data alone. Radio continuum observations sample thermal emission from deeper and presumably colder layers in the nucleus (with depth comparable to several wavelengths), as opposed to mid-IR measurements, which sample only the top $\sim$10 microns. Therefore radio data allow us to measure the thermal gradient, a crucial parameter in understanding the nature and source of cometary activity. The observations would also let us test for the first time the applicability to other comets of the new findings by the Rosetta spacecraft about the interior and energetics of comet 67P. Do other comets have the same thermal behavior and structure?
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
